title: ⭐⭐ Add dynamic elements to reports
text: This page provides a step-by-step correction for adding dynamic elements to a simple MS Word report.

title: ⭐⭐ Add dynamic elements to reports
text:
1 Improve navigation and readability
---
title: My outbreak report
author: Helene Langet
date: "2023-12-31"

format:
  docx:
7    toc: true
8    number-sections: true
9    toc-depth: 2

execute:    
  echo: false               
  warning: false            
---

7

This enables a table of contents (toc) at the beginning of your rendered MS Word report, making it easier for readers to navigate through sections.

8

This option automatically numbers all section headings (e.g., 1, 1.1, 1.2), providing a clear, hierarchical structure.

9

This limits the table of contents to display only two levels of headings.








Important




Remember that YAML is a whitespace-sensitive language where indentation determines the structure

🚫 Do NOT use tabs—they are not recognized.
✅ Use two spaces per indentation level to ensure consistency and avoid errors.

In this example, the TOC settings are applied specifically to the Word document output. If you want these settings to apply to all output formats (like HTML or PDF), move them to a higher level in the YAML header.
When you open the rendered MS Word document, you might see a warning message, as displayed below. Do not worry, this is completely normal and does not indicate an error. This message appears because the document contains dynamic fields, such as the table of contents, cross-references, or figure/table captions. Click “Yes” to ensure all references and the table of contents are properly updated. If you click “No,” the document will still open, but some fields may not reflect the latest changes. This is a standard behavior in MS Word when working with dynamic content.


This document contains fields that may refer to other files. Do you want to update the fields in this document?

---

10

Instead of manually entering a date (e.g., 2023-12-31), this setting automatically updates the date to the last time the MS Word document was generated (but this does not reflect when the source Quarto document was last edited).

11

Formats the date to be displayed in a full, human-readable format December 31, 2023. This improves readability, making the report look more polished.

title: ⭐⭐ Add dynamic elements to reports
text:
4 Reference figures

Figure 1

```{r}
18#| label: fig-1
#| fig-cap: Weekly count of all cases, confirmed cases and deaths
19#| fig-width: 8
20#| fig-height: 4

# Aggregate the data to get the weekly count of all cases, confirmed cases and deaths
weekly_data <- subdf |>
  dplyr::group_by(week) |>
  dplyr::summarise(count = dplyr::n(),
                   confirmed_count = sum(confirmed == "1"),
                   death_count = sum(death == "1"))

# Plot the weekly cases, confirmed cases and deaths
ggplot2::ggplot(weekly_data, ggplot2::aes(x = week)) +
  ggplot2::geom_line(ggplot2::aes(y = count,
                                  color = "All cases"),
                     size = 1) +
  ggplot2::geom_line(ggplot2::aes(y = confirmed_count,
                                  color = "Confirmed cases"),
                     size = 1) +
  ggplot2::geom_line(ggplot2::aes(y = death_count,
                                  color = "Confirmed deaths"),
                     size = 1) +
  ggplot2::labs(x = "Week",
                y = "Count",
                color = "Legend") +
  ggplot2::scale_color_manual(values = c("All cases" = "#440e54",
                                         "Confirmed cases" = "#f8766d",
                                         "Confirmed deaths" = "#128984")) +
  ggplot2::theme_minimal() +
  ggplot2::theme(panel.grid.major.y = ggplot2::element_line(linewidth = 0.5, linetype = "dashed", color = "grey"),
                 panel.grid.minor.y = ggplot2::element_line(linewidth = 0.5, linetype = "dashed", color = "grey"),
                 panel.grid.major.x = ggplot2::element_blank(),
                 panel.grid.minor.x = ggplot2::element_blank())
```

5 Reference code chunks
The logistic regression model uses death as the response variable, and bmi and age as predictor variables. It is implemented in R as shown in the code chunk referenced by Listing 1




Listing 1: R code


```{r}
#| lst-label: lst-test
#| lst-cap: R code

coeffs <- glm(death ~ bmi + age,
              subdf |> dplyr::filter(confirmed == "1"),
              family = binomial)
```





Implement a logistic regression model based on description in the Quarto document.

---

author: Helene Langet

date-format: long

format:
  docx:
23    reference-doc: swisstph_template.docx
    toc: true
    number-sections: true
    toc-depth: 2

execute:    
  echo: false               
  warning: false
---

23

Apply the Swiss TPH template swisstph_template.docx to your MS Word rendered report. Here this means the Word document and Quarto document are located in the same folder. Otherwise you need to indicate the path relative to the QUarto notebook
